doc.title: Estimate revisions
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-31/SICC - A More sluggish fundamentals versus share price resiliency Neutral with a more guarded stance AR glasses TAM upda_2025-08-31

passages.text: This material is neither intended to be distributed to Mainland China Investors nor to provide securities investment consultancy services within the territory of Mainland China. This material or any portion hereof may not be published, sold or redistributed without the written consent of J.P. Morgan.
More sluggish fundamentals versus share price resiliency; Neutral with a more guarded stance; AR glasses TAM updates

SICC reported 2Q25 results on Aug 29, which were a clean miss. We believe SiC substrate industry pricing erosion has outpaced SICC's cost reduction, for both \(6^{\circ}\) and \(8^{\circ}\) products, and SICC has compromised on pricing to get volumes from both international and Chinese customers. We expect this negative trend will linger on in 2H25 and 2026, and we have cut our 2025- 27 estimates significantly. We expect the share price to react negatively to the 2Q25 results, and for consensus 2025- 27 earnings to see meaningful downward revisions. Maintain Neutral and adjust Jun- 26 PT to Rmb52, based on 10x 2027E P/S (vs 12x historical trough P/S since Jan 2023); we suggest investors avoid the stock. SICC's share price has increased \(26\%\) YTD (vs SSE Index up \(11\%\) ), against weakening fundamentals, which we attribute to the bullish camp's optimism on SICC's substrate business prospects from AR glass waveguides. Our analysis suggests 1mn pairs of AR glasses might offer Rmb1.0bn TAM for optical- grade SiC substrates, while some bullish investors expect the volume of AR glasses using SiC substrates for waveguides could reach multi- million units a couple of years out. We do not suggest investors buy on this thesis, as the material roadmap for AR glass waveguides, as well as production timelines and volumes, all have uncertainties ahead. Our research suggests waveguide relevant cost (SiC substrate and processing) could remain as high as Rmb2k+ (\$300+) in the initial mass production. BoM will likely make AR glasses selling price fairly high. Last, since early 2025, industry SiC substrate vendors have received a foundry's request of \(12^{\circ}\) SiC substrates for interposers in advanced packaging, but the concept of SiC interposers is only in the path- finding stage without any further visibility, in our view.

- 2Q25 results a clean miss. Net profit of Rmb2mn missed JPMe Rmb39mn. Revenue of Rmb386mn was down \(5\%\) QoQ and \(21\%\) YoY. GM of \(12.6\%\) corrected from \(24\%\) in both 1Q25 and 2Q25 and missed JPMe \(25\%\) . 1H25 net profit was Rmb11mn, while operating loss was Rmb32mn, given Rmb36mn of government subsidies. For 2H25, we project \(4\%\) HoH growth in revenue and GM capped at low to mid teens, meaning a lack of recovery.

- Pricing erosion outpacing cost reduction. In our Apr SiC sector note (link), we flagged a fast-declining price in \(8^{\circ}\) SiC substrates in both international and China markets. We believe SICC has compromised on pricing to get volumes, and the industry pricing downtrend has outpaced SICC's cost reduction in both \(6^{\circ}\) and \(8^{\circ}\) substrates, and we believe this will continue to weigh on SICC's profitability in the next 12 months. SICC is developing new technology for n-type \(8^{\circ}\) SiC substrates to fend off competition and counter ASP pressure. However, production volume is small now, and the mass production timeline is unclear, subject to yield and cost.
Sources for: Style Exposure - J.P. Morgan Global Markets Strategy; all other tables are company data and J.P. Morgan estimates.

SICC's 2Q25 results were a clean miss. We believe SiC substrate industry pricing erosion has outpaced SICC's cost reduction, for both \(6^{\circ}\) and \(8^{\circ}\) products, and SICC has compromised on pricing to get volumes from both international and Chinese customers. We expect this negative trend will linger on in 2H25 and 2026, and we have cut our 2025- 27 estimates significantly. We expect the share price to react negatively to the 2Q25 results, and for consensus 2025- 27 earnings to see meaningful downward revisions.

The bullish camp is optimistic on SICC's substrate business prospects from AR glass waveguides. Our analysis suggests 1mn pairs of AR glasses might offer Rmb1.0bn TAM for optical- grade SiC substrates, while some bullish investors expect the volume of AR glasses using SiC substrates for waveguides could reach multi- million units a couple of years out. We do not suggest investors buy on this thesis, as the material roadmap for AR glass waveguides, as well as production timelines and volumes, all have uncertainties ahead. Our research suggests waveguide relevant cost (SiC substrate and processing) could remain as high as Rmb2k+ \((\) 300+)$ in the initial mass production. The BoM will likely make AR glasses selling price fairly high.
Our Jun- 26 PT of Rmb52 is based on 10x 2027E P/S (vs 12x historical trough P/S since Jan 2023; repeated revenue misses making the multiple high).

- Potentially more competition for international customer orders. Two of SICC's Chinese peers are building SiC substrate manufacturing capacity in Penang, Malaysia, aiming to capture international customers' supply chain management needs. This will increase not only industry capacity but also competition against SICC, which has benefitted from an early-mover advantage in the international 8" SiC market, in our view. With the proceeds from the HK IPO, SICC will also execute its overseas capacity building project.

- Views on stock trading. SICC's share price has increased 26% YTD and outperformed the SSE index by 11%. We suspect many SICC investors may be looking beyond sluggish fundamentals in 2025 and in 2026, as they have very high expectations on AR glasses and derive stock value from long-term prospects (8" and 12" high-purity optical-grade SiC substrates used for AR glass waveguides). In 1H25, SICC announced a partnership with Sunny Optical, while SICC approaches global AR glass OEMs as well. In a fairly optimistic scenario, the timeline could be volume production orders in 2H26 and material revenue contribution in 2027. However, we believe there could be multiple uncertainties for the SiC substrate industry ahead, including waveguide roadmap, schedule and volumes. Hence, we would not suggest investors buy on this optimism.

- 1mn pairs of AR glasses offering an Rmb1.0bn TAM for SiC substrates? Based on our research, the relevant cost for one pair of AR glasses using SiC substrates for waveguides could be Rmb1k for SiC substrates and another Rmb1k or less for substrate processing (i.e. etching, etc.) two years out or even later (yet, much higher now). For a ball-park analysis, if we assume 1mn pairs of AR glasses using SiC substrates for waveguides and one piece of 12" SiC substrate priced at Rmb10k and supporting 10 pairs, we derive the TAM at Rmb1.0bn. If we assume SICC takes 30-50% market share, it implies Rmb300-500mn revenue contribution. We estimate SICC's SiC substrate revenue at Rmb1.3bn in 2025 (total revenue JPMie Rmb1.6bn). The comparison indicates that if the AR glasses catalyst comes true, the incremental contribution could be meaningful.

- Cut earnings significantly. We project SICC to register an operating loss again in 2025 but a slim operating profit of Rmb45mn and Rmb212mn in 2026 and 2027. We factor in Rmb130mn revenue and 20% GM for optical substrates in 2027. SICC's market cap is Rmb32.7bn, which we believe has factored in too much optimism. We adjust our Jun-26 PT to Rmb52, based on 10x 2027E P/S (vs 12x historical trough P/S since Jan 2023; repeated revenue misses making the multiple high). Our prior Jun-26 PT of Rmb50 was based on a 45x 2027E P/E and implies a 6.3x 2027E P/S. We have changed the valuation method given earnings volatility and we nudge up the P/S multiple to reflect positive tech sector sentiment and align with its historical trend. We maintain our Neutral rating on the stock and suggest that investors avoid the stock.

SICC - A (Neutral; Price Target: Rmb52.00)

We expect this negative trend will linger on in 2H25 and 2026, and we have cut our 2025- 27 estimates significantly. We expect the share price to react negatively to the 2Q25 results, and for consensus 2025- 27 earnings to see meaningful downward revisions.

The bullish camp is optimistic on SICC's substrate business prospects from AR glass waveguides. J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex-Australia and ex-India) and U.K. small- and mid-cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe.
